placeMetadata.name: Mehrangarh Fort

sources.snippet: Sitting atop a 400-feet-high hill, the beautiful Mehrangarh Fort commands the landscape of Jodhpur with its architectural brilliance and grandeur. The foundation stone of this majestic fort was laid by Rao Jodha in the mid-15 th century. Built over a period of 500 years, the fort bears testimony to the glorious era of the erstwhile ruling dynasty, and houses possibly the best museum in Rajasthan displaying paintings, arms and armoury, textiles, decorative arts and other prized exhibits.
sources.shortName: 12 Tourist Places to Visit in Jodhpur 2024: Timings, Entry Fee

sources.snippet: Mehrangarh, also known as Mehran Fort was built by Rao Jodha in 1459 in Jodhpur, is one of the largest forts in the country. It is situated at the top of a 410 feet elevated hill and guarded by massive walls. One of the most easily recognisable forts in Jodhpur, it has appeared in many Hollywood and Bollywood productions such as The Lion King, The Dark Knight Rises, and the more recent - Thugs of Hindostan.

sources.snippet: Standing tall and proud on a rocky hill, Mehrangarh Fort epitomises grandeur and history. The fort's intricate architecture, expansive courtyards, and well-preserved palaces like the Sheesh Mahal (Mirror Palace) and Phool Mahal (Flower Palace) are a testament to the craftsmanship of a bygone era.

Mehrangarh is a historic fort located in Jodhpur, Rajasthan, India. It stands on a hilltop, rising about 122 m (400 ft) above the surrounding plains, and the complex spans 1,200 acres (486 hectares). It was initially built around 1459 by the Rajput ruler of Rathore clan Rao Jodha,though most of the existing structure is from the 17th century built by his successors. The fort has seven gates, which includes main entrance Jai Pol (meaning 'victory gate'), built by Maharaja Man Singh to commemorate his victories over the Jaipur and Bikaner armies in 1806. The Fattehpol (lit.‚Äâ'victory gate'), commemorates victory of Maharaja Ajit Singh over the Mughals. The English writer and Nobel Prize winner, Rudyard Kipling, described the fort as "a palace that might have been built by Titans and colored by the morning sun."A beautiful magnificent fort with a magnificent history. Ancient lovely building with multiple floors. For the convenience of tourists a paid lift is installed. It takes you to the top most floor and then you can come down watching museum and temples along the way. Well maintained.
There is a museum and 3 to 4 temples inside. You need atleast an hour here. The ticket costs around 200 rupees The fort opens at around 9 am. There is a light & music show too here.
You can take a guide too. They are government certified as they say & charge around Rs 400 but you can negotiate to rs 200 to rs 250
Good place to visit. You feel in awe.

üìåAn Unforgettable Journey Through Time -
Stepping into Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur is not just visiting a monument; it's a profound journey back in time. Perched dramatically on a 400-foot-high cliff, this colossal fortress is a masterpiece of architecture, history, and culture that will leave you in awe. From the moment you approach its immense, towering walls, you understand why Rudyard Kipling called it "the work of giants."

The fort's exterior, carved from burnished red sandstone, seems to merge seamlessly with the rugged hill, creating an image of impregnable strength and natural beauty. But the true magic lies within. The intricately carved palaces, such as the stunning Moti Mahal, Phool Mahal, and Sheesh Mahal, are a testament to the opulence and artistic brilliance of the Rajput rulers. Each courtyard and room tells a story, beautifully preserved and brought to life by the excellent audio guide, which is highly recommended and well worth the minimal cost.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Mehrangarh is the incredible panoramic view it offers. From the ramparts, you can gaze out over the "Blue City" of Jodhpur, a sea of indigo houses that creates a mesmerizing contrast against the arid landscape. The feeling of standing at this vantage point, with the wind carrying the echoes of centuries of history, is simply breathtaking.

Magnificent fort with breathtaking views of Jodhpur‚Äôs Blue City. The museum is well-curated, showcasing royal artifacts, arms, and palanquins. Architecture is grand and well-preserved. Entry is a bit pricey, and it involves a lot of walking/climbing, but totally worth the experience.

The majestic fort boasts art and history to itself.

**Jaswant Thada, Jodhpur**

**Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (4.5/5)**

**Location:** Jaswant Thada is a stunning white marble memorial located just a short distance from Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur, Rajasthan. Perched on a small hill, it offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Blue City and the imposing Mehrangarh Fort.

**Architecture & Ambience:**
This architectural gem, often referred to as the "Taj Mahal of Marwar," is a serene and peaceful retreat. Built in 1899 in memory of Maharaja Jaswant Singh II, the structure is made of intricately carved white marble that glows golden in the sunlight. The delicate latticework, domed pavilions, and beautifully landscaped gardens create a tranquil atmosphere, making it a perfect escape from the bustling city.

**Highlights:**
- The main memorial houses portraits of Jodhpur‚Äôs rulers and a royal cenotaph.
- The serene lake beside the monument enhances its beauty.
- The cool breeze and quiet surroundings make it an ideal spot for photography and relaxation.
- The vantage point offers one of the best views of Jodhpur‚Äôs blue houses and Mehrangarh Fort.

**Visitor Experience:**
Entry is reasonably priced, and the site is well-maintained. It‚Äôs less crowded than other tourist spots in Jodhpur, allowing visitors to explore at a leisurely pace. Guides are available for those interested in learning about the history, but the site is equally enjoyable for silent admiration.

**Final Verdict:**
Jaswant Thada is a must-visit for history buffs, architecture lovers, and anyone seeking a peaceful moment with a spectacular view. Its ethereal beauty and historical significance make it one of Jodhpur‚Äôs most underrated attractions.

**Tip:** Visit during sunrise or sunset for the most magical lighting and cooler temperatures.

**Highly recommended!**

A Royal Experience Like No Other ‚Äì Umaid Bhawan Palace is Pure Magic!

Staying at Umaid Bhawan Palace was nothing short of a dream come true. From the moment we arrived at this majestic sandstone marvel, we were transported into a world of regal opulence, impeccable hospitality, and timeless elegance.

The palace itself is a masterpiece‚Äîan architectural wonder blending Indo-Deco style with Rajput grandeur. Set amidst lush gardens and perched high above Jodhpur, the views of the Blue City and the Mehrangarh Fort are absolutely breathtaking.

What truly sets Umaid Bhawan apart is the warmth and professionalism of the staff. Every member of the team especially Mr. Gordhan Singh Ji, Mr. Sikander Singh Ji, Mr. Jabar Singh Ji, Mr. Sajjan Singh Ji, Mr. Karan Singh Ji, Mr. Hukum Singh Ji and Mr. Umaid Singh Ji made us feel like royalty. Their attention to detail, genuine smiles, and readiness to go the extra mile made our stay extraordinary.

Our Suite Room was spacious, beautifully furnished, and steeped in history, yet equipped with every modern comfort. The bed was luxurious, the bathroom was grand, and the heritage decor added a unique charm that made us feel like we were living in a bygone era.

Dining at the palace was a culinary delight. Each meal at Risala and Pillars was not just delicious, but also beautifully presented, with a menu that honored local Rajasthani flavors while offering international finesse.

We also thoroughly enjoyed the spa, the vintage car tour, and simply strolling through the manicured gardens. Every corner of the property tells a story, and the history is palpable in the best way.

Balsamand Lake is a lake situated 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) from Jodhpur on Jodhpur-Mandore Road. This lake is a popular picnic spot, built in 1159 AD by Gurjara-Pratihara rulers. It was designed as a water reservoir to provide water to Mandore. The lake has a length of one kilometre (0.62 mi), breadth of 50 metres (160 ft) and a depth of 15 metres (49 ft).
The Balsamand Lake Palace was built later as a summer palace on its shore. The lake is surrounded by lush green gardens that house groves of trees like¬†mango,¬†papaya,¬†pomegranate,¬†guava¬†and¬†plum. Animals and birds like the jackal and peacock also call this place home.
Balsamand Lake is an artificial lake that was built way back in 1159 AD by Balak Rao Parihar as a water reservoir to cater for Mandore. One kilometre long, 50 m broad and 15 m deep; the lake is located in the middle of a manicured garden full of mango, papaya, pomegranate, guava and plum trees. Jackal and peacock are the prominent guests in the garden. There is an impressive red sandstone summer palace on the shores of the lake, which is now converted into a five-star property. Make a point to watch out for pesky monkeys when walking the nature trails. The area is a popular picnic spot for locals.

reviews.reviewText:
The Mehrangarh Fort is one of the largest forts in the country and is known for its architectural beauty and historical significance. The fort houses several palaces, each with its own unique features and history.
Phool Mahal is an exquisite palace known for its intricate gold filigree work, paintings, and mirror work. It was created as a pleasure dome by Maharaja Abhaya Singh and was used for entertainment and festivities.

**A Majestic Marvel in the Blue City**

Mehrangarh Fort, towering 400 feet above Jodhpur, is not just a historical monument but a breathtaking symbol of Rajasthan‚Äôs grandeur. Built in the 15th century by Rao Jodha, the fort‚Äôs imposing walls and intricate architecture leave visitors spellbound.

### **Highlights:**
- **Architecture & Views:** The fort‚Äôs massive gates, ornate palaces (like Moti Mahal and Phool Mahal), and expansive courtyards showcase Rajput craftsmanship. The panoramic views of Jodhpur‚Äôs blue houses from the ramparts are unforgettable.
- **Museum:** One of the best in Rajasthan, it houses an exquisite collection of palanquins, arms, costumes, and royal artifacts. The audio guide (narrated by Shah Rukh Khan) adds a fascinating touch.
- **Cultural Experience:** Live folk music performances and the famous "Jodhpur RIFF" festival make the fort come alive with Rajasthani culture.
- **Chokelao Bagh & Caf√©:** A serene garden and rooftop caf√© offering delicious local snacks with a stunning fort backdrop.

### **Tips:**
- Visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds and heat.
- Don‚Äôt miss the "Chamunda Devi Temple" and the thrilling "Jayapol" victory gate.
- Photography enthusiasts will love the endless photo opportunities.

**** Mehrangarh Fort is a must-visit for history buffs, architecture lovers, and anyone seeking a glimpse into Rajasthan‚Äôs royal past. Its sheer scale, beauty, and cultural richness make it one of India‚Äôs finest forts.

**** A mesmerizing journey through time‚Äîhighly recommended!

The Phool Mahal, or "Palace of Flowers," is one of the most exquisitely decorated and historically significant chambers within the Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur, Rajasthan.
Built in the 18th century by Maharaja Abhaya Singh, it served as a private audience hall and a space for royal entertainment and leisure. The name "Phool Mahal" itself suggests its vibrant beauty, as its interiors are designed to evoke the essence of a blooming flower.
Here's what makes it so remarkable:
* Opulent Decor: The palace is renowned for its extravagant decoration, featuring intricate frescoes, elaborate carvings, and richly colored wall paintings. The walls and ceilings are adorned with gold leaf work, often using gold brought from Gujarat, creating a lavish and regal ambiance.
* Artistic Excellence: You'll find a stunning display of Rajput and Mughal artistry, including detailed mirror work, delicate filigree, and vivid murals depicting royal life, traditional motifs, and even illustrations from the famous Raga Mala series (Indian classical music compositions). Portraits of Jodhpur's ancestors also grace the walls.
* Exclusive Use: Unlike some other parts of the fort, Phool Mahal was a private and exclusive chamber, primarily used by the Maharaja for private gatherings, entertainment by female dancers, and as a personal retreat. This exclusivity is reflected in its less accessible location within the fort.
* Historical Significance: It stands as a testament to the grandeur and artistic patronage of the Rathore rulers of Jodhpur, offering a glimpse into the lavish lifestyle of the royal family.
Today, Phool Mahal is a key part of the Mehrangarh Fort museum, allowing visitors to step back in time and admire its unique blend of architectural beauty and artistic splendor.

reviews.reviewText: It's NOT a tourist place. It is a highly RESTRICTED AREA which is Out of Bounds for the General Public. The Palace was once an area which housed "Raika Community" and their camels. Gradually, in the year 1663 by the queen of Maharaja Jaswant Singh I (Hadi Rani Jasrang De), constructed an exquisite lawn and Garden in this area, hence renaming it as "Raika Bagh". Later a Place cum Garden Complex was constructed along with Maharaja's Official Guest House, further renaming it as "Raika Bagh Palace". It was here that in 1883, Swami Dayanand Saraswati came to Jodhpur. The arrangements for his public audience were made in the public ground of this palace only. He gave his sermons here itself. Even Jaswant Singh used to listen to Swami Dayanand in this palace. But Unfortunately, a tragedy occurred when Swami Dayanand Saraswati was poisoned on 29th September 1883, while being royal guest. It is said it was Dayananda‚Äôs own cook who conspired with the court dancer to mix crushed Glass in his milk. It is even Rumoured that Queen Zubeida's unsatisfied soul (Second wife of King Hanwant Singh I of Marwar, who died with him in a Mysterious Plane Crash) still  haunts this palace and the royal family's school near the palace.

placeMetadata.name: Jodhpur Camel Safari & Overnight Stay in Desert

sources.snippet: Camel safaris in Jodhpur offer a unique and unforgettable way to explore the stunning landscapes of the Thar Desert. These safaris provide an opportunity to experience the local culture, witness the desert's diverse flora and fauna, and enjoy breathtaking sunsets over the sand dunes. Camel safaris are a popular activity for adventure seekers and nature lovers visiting Jodhpur.
sources.shortName: 22 Places to Visit in Jodhpur in 2025

sources.snippet: Welcome to Desert land ‚ÄúMARU DESH‚Äù known as THAR The Great Indian Desert, Rajasthan desert camel safari, Jodhpur camel safari.
sources.shortName: Castle View ‚Äì Welcome To The World Of Heritage

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Embarking on a "Jodhpur Camel Safari & Overnight Stay in Desert" is an adventure that immerses you in the enchanting beauty of the Thar Desert. With various packages available, ranging from short excursions to Osian‚Äîsteeped in Hindu and Jain heritage‚Äîto longer treks towards Jaisalmer, these safaris are perfect for those eager to explore the region's rich culture and history.
placeMetadata.address: 52V9+P8V, Phase 1st, Sangriya, Jodhpur, Rajasthan 342005, India

reviews.reviewText:
Absolutely phenomenal experience! From the moment we arrived, the hospitality was outstanding. The dessert safari tour was exhilarating, the camel ride was a unique touch, and the traditional food was delicious. Sumer went above and beyond to ensure we were comfortable and well taken care of throughout. Highly recommend this tour for anyone looking for an unforgettable desert adventure with top-notch hospitality.

Additionally, we were touched by the extended care provided by Sumer‚Äôs dad, who ensured our car parked a little away from their house was safe and secure. It truly exemplified their commitment to hospitality and guest satisfaction. Very humble family, and Sumer‚Äôs vision of providing free education to kids in his village is a very selfless vision. Overall, a five-star experience in every aspect!

It was a lovely experience to visit Samer and his village. We are a couple and had opted for the half day camel and jeep safari. The pick up from our hotel (Radisson) was in a quality SUV and the trip upto the Osian desert outskirts was smooth. We also visited the Sacchiyay Mata temple which offered some lovely prayer and ancient architecture. We were met by Samer and the jeep safari that followed through the Osian sand shrubbery and desert outskirts was quite a thrilling experience and could spot some antelope and peacocks. We reached his quaint village and he has a lovely homestay as well. Meeting his family and his own farm camels and goats and talking with the lovely man was a nice experience. My gf (from Thailand) felt at home as she cooked with Samers mom in the traditional village kitchen and we really enjoyed the lovely home cooked meal as well. It was also heartwarming to see his voluntary enterprise to teach his village children English and Computers and meeting the kids was a highlight. And then to end the trip with our lovely camels, Mr. Jigar and Michael Jackson was just stunning in the sunset. The camels are well trained and gentle animals .. the ride very comfortable and fun at the same time ... the location itself through the camel ride just breathtaking. All in all, I would highly recommend this away from the rush and such an earthly and true village experience as you get to interact with the real flavors of the rajasthan and it's beautiful culture. The ride back to our hotel in the car was also well taken care of and our hosts were lovely, polite and extremely hospitable. A 5/5 for a real and truly deeper experience of the camels and culture of rajasthan.

A different experience in Jodhpur was really being looked forward to and this village was the one....We were treated with kindness and friendliness by the hosts! We were welcomed in Rajasthani style with utmost respect and treated with much affection and kindness.Home-made food was served and it was very delicious. The rooms were very clean and well.
Camel safari and desert rides with the host were very nice for us. We were taken to nice view points by him and very nice pictures of our gang were clicked. Overall, a different and nice experience I can recommend !

Absolutely amazing experience! The camel ride was great fun and went for a good amount of time. We were welcomed to their small village and shared a delicious meal in their family home. We were amazed at their hospitality and inspired by the local school/education lessons they have set up for children within their home. They use a portion of their family income to fund the education lessons for small children in their village. We wished we stayed for the home stay. We definitely recommend!!

We had a wonderful stay with Sumer and his family. We stayed 1 night and did a camel safari and a walk. We got tasty traditional food and even could help a bit in the kitchen. In the night we decided to sleep under the stars, but could have stayed in the hut as well. The hut was very new and the bathroom big and clean.

Sumer's camel ride and dinner deserves a 5 star rating. He is very friendly, polite and accommodating and so are his family members who co-host his guests. He wishes to bring development to his village through his business and I would contribute to that by visiting him again. Sumer is very open to feedback and genuinely tries to improve the guest experience. The funniest and the best part was him running with the camels to click excellent photographs. I wish him luck!

That was an amazing, exciting, and breathtaking experience in Osian, Jodpur.
We did some activities such as JEEP Safari(You can find deer and fox if you are lucky ;)),parasailing at desert(super exciting), sunrise camel safari(if you go to camp site, the riding is only about 10 mins, but here they took us for riding about 1 hour.  Mr. Sumer, our host, took so many high-quality photos for us.)

At night, the host mother cooked traditional dinner for us. We could also try to make chapati. After dinner, the beds were prepared outside of our room, and we were lying down and sleeping under millions of stars.
The shower room was just renewed, so it was very clean and comfortable.

I strongly recommend you to stay here. You will definitely get a memorable experience in your journey.

Firstly this is a MUST VISIT Place if you are looking for authentic safari and village stay experience, the guide(owner&son) is completely SAFE to travel to/with, Mr.Dhannaram the owner was waiting near our parked car on road for 3.5hrs untill we return to car as me n my wife were not feeling safe. Then Mr.Sumer took us on camel ride of 30-40min to his village home stay and as we entered they welcomed us by offering traditional ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡§ó‡§°‡•Ä to wear. Post that we checked the Hut rooms and we were Awestruck by noticing the clean room and specially western washroom.Then Sumer explained instead of making more huts for tourist he invested that money in opening a FREE computer class in his house for villages kids to learn typing and English which was so Inspiring and motivating for us. Later Sumer's mother served us ultimately tasty Rajasthani food and chaay!(mirchi ki chutney was the best).The whole family was very humble in nature and they provided us with great service. Lastly we took jeep safari to our car location. This was one of the best experience we had in our trip to Rajasthan.

placeMetadata.name: Umaid Bhawan Museum

sources.snippet: The last royal palace erected before India's independence was the Umaid Bhawan Palace. It is also known as the Chittar Palace because of its position atop Chittar Hill. Its foundations were established in 1929, and it was finished in 1943.The Taj Group of Hotels first allowed visitors to the palace who wanted to experience living in a royal house in 2006.
sources.shortName: 6 Unmissable monuments in Jodhpur and the history behind them

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Umaid Bhawan Museum, located in Jodhpur city, is a popular tourist spot and one of the best attractions in the area. The museum is housed within a portion of the majestic Umaid Bhawan Palace, with other parts serving as a luxurious hotel and residence for the royal family. It showcases an impressive collection of antiques that belonged to the maharajas and displays intricate artwork, providing insight into the history of the Suryvanshi dynasty.
placeMetadata.address: Umed Bhawan Palace Rd, Cantt Area, Jodhpur, Rajasthan 342011, India

reviews.reviewText:
It‚Äôs a great place for history buffs, architecture lovers, and anyone wanting to get a feel of royal life in Rajasthan.
The palace offers a perfect blend of culture, history, luxury, and stunning architecture.
It‚Äôs less crowded compared to other tourist spots, so you can enjoy it at a relaxed pace.

Good place to visit i personally liked the architecture of the palace. The Stone used here makes it more beautiful and different from the other palaces of India. Also I forgot to add the vintage car museum it was my personal favourite.

Good place to visit in Jodhpur.  Many antique articles are kept in museum. Vintage cars are also seen outside the museum. Umaid bhavan is partly open for the public as the royal family stays in the remaining part. The Guide informed that this palace was built during the famine in the 1920s when the then Maharaja Umaid Singh offered the people food for their work so that people would not sleep without food. People worked in building the palace and in lieu of it they received food. Construction work started in 1929 and was completed in 1943. The museum opens at 10 am and closes at 5 pm on all the days of the week. So one has to reach at least before 3 pm to visit this museum completely.

Umaid Bhawan Museum is partially open for the tourists or visitors remaining part is a hotel which is not accessible to the tourists untill you are not booked the resort to stay. Here present king is also stay in the umaid bhawan which was told by the one of the guide.

Here is vintage car collection which you can see.
Building looks so stunning, but personally I like the place but nothing much to visit inside.
As most of the place is occupied by the hotel.

Beautiful museum in jodhpur. They have many items of Royal family - vintage watch collection,  vintage car collection,  many swords, photos of the royal family and much more.

It's good experience to know how kings lived like. Recommend to take a guide as they tell interesting stories

Umaid Bhavan is one of the most stunning palaces in India, blending Rajput heritage with Art Deco architecture. Part of it is still the royal residence, another section is a luxury Taj hotel, and one wing houses a museum open to the public. The palace sits atop Chittar Hill, giving panoramic views of Jodhpur and the Mehrangarh Fort.

The museum is small but elegant ‚Äì showcasing royal artifacts, vintage clocks, weapons, and a classic car collection that history lovers will enjoy. The palace gardens are beautifully maintained and perfect for photography.

‚úîÔ∏è Highlights:

Beautiful Indo-Deco architecture

Museum with artifacts & vintage cars üöó

Taj Palace hotel experience (for those who stay/dine)

Great panoramic views of the Blue City

‚ö†Ô∏è Tips:

Museum is closed on certain holidays ‚Äì check timings before visiting.

Visit in the morning or late afternoon for best light.

Entry ticket is affordable, but hotel dining/stay is premium.

Umaid Bhavan is not just a palace ‚Äì it‚Äôs a symbol of Jodhpur‚Äôs royal legacy, combining history, luxury, and elegance. A must-visit spot when in the Blue City!

A must visit tourist attraction in Jodhpur City. Magnificence of the Maharajas on Display here.

Some of the Vintage Cars of the Maharaja on display also make an interesting watch.

The museum showcases fascinating heirlooms: antique clocks (many still ticking), royal crockery, weapons, textiles, banners (like one from Queen Victoria), paintings, stuffed animals, and photos telling the saga of Jodhpur‚Äôs rulers

placeMetadata.name: Caf√© Sheesh Mahal

sources.snippet: Situated within the compound of Mehrangarh Fort is the glass palace of Jodhpur, popularly known as Sheesh Mahal. This magnificent piece of architecture is adorned with walls of mirror work that stretch across ceilings and to the floors. It is superimposed by the mirror work of brightly painted religious figures cast in plaster.
sources.shortName: Best Places to Visit in Jodhpur, Attractions and Points of Interest- Rajasthan Tourism

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Caf√© Sheesh Mahal is a hidden gem located just outside the northern gate of Sardar Market in Jodhpur. The caf√© may not look impressive from the outside or inside, but it offers a peaceful retreat from the city's chaos. The interior is usually quiet, making it an ideal spot to unwind with a book and enjoy a cup of coffee or mango lassi. This quaint caf√© provides a good selection of beverages and a tranquil atmosphere for visitors seeking relaxation.
placeMetadata.address: 1, Pal Haveli Inn, opposite Clock Tower, near Gulab Sagar, Jodhpur, Rajasthan 342001, India

reviews.reviewText: Lovely clean quiet space. I had grilled cheese and tomato and a sweet lassi. Both were delicious, good portions and reasonably priced. I will return here.

Beautiful small coffee shop with a view of the clock tower and a great coffee machine.

I had a cappuccino and a Nutella banana crepe, both were really good. Happy to have found a great cappuccino and crepe as it's not always available while traveling so it was a satisfying breakfast.

For anyone visiting Jodhpur, Caf√© Sheesh Mahal is an essential stop, especially for tourists seeking a delightful blend of modern comforts and traditional charm. Situated in the heart of the city, this caf√© offers a serene escape from the vibrant streets of Jodhpur. The ambiance is unparalleled, making it one of the most inviting spots in the city. With its elegant decor and intimate seating, it provides the perfect setting to unwind, enjoy a meal, or simply soak in the atmosphere.

A highlight of the menu is undoubtedly their lassi, which is both refreshing and indulgent. Rich in flavor and incredibly creamy, it is an ideal choice, particularly on a warm day. Equally impressive are their pancakes, light and fluffy, served with a variety of toppings to suit all tastes. Whether you're looking for a quick snack or a leisurely meal, Caf√© Sheesh Mahal delivers with its thoughtfully curated menu.

Its central location makes it an ideal stop for tourists, providing a convenient respite after exploring the nearby attractions. The staff are warm and attentive, ensuring an experience that is as enjoyable as it is relaxed.

In a city steeped in culture and history, Caf√© Sheesh Mahal offers a refreshing yet authentic experience. It perfectly encapsulates the fusion of Jodhpur‚Äôs rich heritage with a contemporary dining environment, making it a must-visit for anyone seeking both culinary satisfaction and a memorable ambiance.

A great place to escape the busy city life and have a cup of coffee !! The cappuccino was really good with freshly ground beans ‚òïÔ∏è the pancakes with lemon were delicious and fresh, we also got the cheese and tomato toastie which was good but had a masala paste inside which we did not see listed on the menu :)

Coffee is excellent and soft drinks over looking the market and near the clock tower.  Facilities also for a quick confort break.  I would highly recommend.

Great coffee. Cafe is upstairs in a cool relaxed environment above the street below. Feels authentic, like I‚Äôve stepped back in time 50 or so years. Ordered an espresso americano and a delicious banana lassi.
Coffee was very good (we are Italian), atmosphere was great and the owner is a very nice person. Calm place to relax!

placeMetadata.name: Ganesh Temple

sources.snippet: The Ganesh Temple in Ratanada, Jodhpur, is a revered spiritual site dedicated to Lord Ganesha, the elephant-headed deity known as the remover of obstacles and the god of beginnings. Nestled in the vibrant city known for its majestic forts and palaces, this temple attracts not only devotees but also tourists eager to experience its serene ambience and architectural beauty. The temple is adorned with intricate carvings and vibrant decorations, reflecting the rich cultural heritage of Rajasthan.

reviews.reviewText: I am fully satisfied with the services of Marwar Regency Hotel. Specially the food of this hotel was sooo yummy. Not too much spicy and oily. All ingredients were balanced .I had taken food at different places during the trip but when I compared, the hotel food was better than others. All staff of the hotel were very supportive. Thanks to all of the staff of Marwar Regency Hotel to make my trip comfortable and safe.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ

I recently stayed at this hotel, and unfortunately, my experience was far from satisfactory. While the rooms were small but clean, the amenities left much to be desired. The rooms lacked basic essentials like toilet paper, slippers, shaving kits, and handwash. Furthermore, no drinking water was provided, which is quite unacceptable.

Additionally, there was a lot of noise from the lift mechanism throughout the night, which was very disturbing and made it difficult to sleep.

Considering the price being asked at ‚Çπ2200 per night, it is definitely not worth it. In my opinion, the maximum value for this hotel should be between ‚Çπ1000 to ‚Çπ1200 per night. After a lot of negotiations, I managed to pay ‚Çπ1800, as I was tired and didn‚Äôt want to explore other options.

Overall, I was disappointed with the lack of amenities, the high price for what was offered, and the constant noise. I would not recommend staying here unless there are significant improvements.

placeMetadata.name: City Palace

sources.snippet: Known for their beautiful structures, detailed edifices and age-old architecture, the Forts And Palaces in Rajasthan are the very evidence of this land‚Äôs rich culture and heritage. Scattered all around the state, these forts and palaces are unique in their history, with every single one more grand than the other. Some of these palaces, like the Umaid Bhawan Palace, amongst others, have also been converted into luxury and heritage resorts and hotels in present times.
sources.shortName: 50 Forts And Palaces in Rajasthan That You Must Visit!

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: City Palace in Rajasthan is a stunning example of the state's rich cultural heritage. The intricate architecture and historical significance make it a must-visit destination. Many of the palaces, including City Palace, have been transformed into luxurious heritage resorts and hotels, offering visitors a chance to immerse themselves in the grandeur of the past. Each palace has its own unique history, making them all worth exploring for anyone interested in the region's regal past.

reviews.reviewText: This is an experience in itself. This property is divided into 3 parts. One is the personal residence of the king, second is of Taj group and a small portion is open for the public. It's a life history of the king and his ancestors. Bright and vibrant colours cover the whole decor. Every picture has a story to tell. There is also a portion showcasing vintage cars. Small eateries and some options related to the royal family are also available for sale. Do take a guide. It's helpful.

Jodhpur is a city located in the state of Rajasthan in northern India, with a population of 1.03 million (2011). The old part of the city is surrounded by an impressive 9.5 km long wall with 101 bastions and seven gates. The city is renowned for its richly carved stone buildings, especially the red sandstone houses in Sadar Basar and the temple in Dhan Market (the grain market). The newer part of the city outside the wall also features notable buildings, particularly the Umaid Bhawan Palace with its 347 rooms, built between 1929 and 1944, considered a prime example of Indian Art Deco architecture.

Mehrangarh Fort, situated on a 125-meter high rock in the old city, dominates the city's skyline. The fort, now a museum, contains several palaces.

Approximately 200 meters northwest of the fort on a plateau lies Jaswant Thada, a memorial to Maharaja Jaswant Singh, built in white marble in 1899.

Jodhpur is also known for its small-scale industries and crafts, including textile production, dyeing, leatherwork, metal tools, bicycles, marble work, and carpet weaving. The city is home to an important base for the Indian Air Force.

Jodhpur is often referred to as the "Blue City" because many of its houses are painted blue. Originally, the blue color signified that the house was inhabited by a Brahmin.

The city was founded in 1459 by the Rajput ruler Rao Jodha on the trade route between Delhi and Gujarat, which facilitated its rapid growth. Rao Jodha conquered much of the surrounding area and established the princely state of Marwar, which came under the Mughal Empire in 1561. During the 18th century, as Mughal power waned, Marwar fell under Maratha control. In 1818, Marwar came under British rule, and Jodhpur became part of Rajasthan in 1949.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Jodhpur, often referred to as the 'Blue City' for its stunning indigo-painted houses, is a treasure trove of history and architectural marvels. At the heart of this vibrant city lies the majestic Mehrangarh Fort, a towering fortress that has stood since 1459, offering breathtaking views and a glimpse into the royal past of Rajasthan. As you wander through its halls, you'll encounter a rich collection of artifacts, including exquisite paintings and sculptures that tell the stories of the Maharajas who once ruled this land. But the allure of Jodhpur doesn't stop there; the city is dotted with other remarkable structures, each with its own unique charm and history, waiting to be explored.

From the serene beauty of Jaswant Thada, a white marble memorial that honors the last ruler of Jodhpur, to the luxurious Umaid Bhawan Palace, where you can experience a taste of royal life, Jodhpur's castles and palaces offer a captivating journey through time. Whether you're seeking the grandeur of historical sites or the tranquility of picturesque lakes like Bal Samand, Jodhpur invites you to immerse yourself in its rich heritage. So pack your bags and get ready to uncover the enchanting stories behind these magnificent castles that define this incredible city.

placeMetadata.name: Jaswant Thada

sources.snippet: Built in the 19 th century by Maharaja Sardar Singh in memory of his beloved father Maharaja Jaswant Singh II, the Jaswant Thada is a cenotaph that serves as the royal Marwar family‚Äôs cremation ground as well. The majestic structure consists of extremely thin and polished sheets of marble carved intricately, emitting a warm glow upon the Sun‚Äôs illumination. The Cenotaph is spread across a large area featuring beautifully carved gazebos, a lake, and a garden which enhance the aesthetic appeal of the structure.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Jodhpur for Travelling Architect

sources.snippet: Along with the clock tower, Sardar Singh also erected a memorial to his father Jaswant Singh ‚Äì but this is no ordinary kiosk. Hindus often honor their ancestors along with deities, and Rajasthanis developed a distinctive form of cenotaph: the chhatri‚ÄÇ(umbrella) with a dome topping a set of columns on an elevated base. After witnessing massive and powerful white mausoleums such as the Taj Mahal, the Rathores erected a few full-fledged temples dedicated to illustrious members of the dynasty.
sources.shortName: The Architecture of Jodhpur, India‚Äôs Blue City

sources.snippet: The Taj Mahal in Agra has captivated all of us since we were young. After all, Emperor Shah Jahan built this monument as a sign of love for his cherished wife, Mumtaz Mahal, whose tomb is located within. But did you know there is another Taj Mahal in Jodhpur's Blue City that Sardar Singh constructed in loving memory of his father?
sources.shortName: 6 Unmissable monuments in Jodhpur and the history behind them

sources.snippet: Built in the memory of Maharaja Jaswant Singhhill, this remarkable white marble memorial is locally describes as the "Taj Mahal of Marwar". The main hall of the monument has been built as a temple where regular "worship and rituals" are performed. Tip: Do try to visit this cenotaph during sunset to take incredible photographs.
sources.shortName: Top 5 architectural marvels to visit in Jodhpur

sources.snippet: Your visit to the Mehrangarh Fort will definitely include a visit to Jaswant Thada. That is because this monument lies in the vicinity of the fort and is a beautiful structure in white. This structure is replete with opulent domes that offer stunning views of the area nearby.
sources.shortName: 10 Historical Places in Jodhpur

sources.snippet: It is a special monument built by Maharaja Sardar Singh in 1899 to remember a former ruler named Jaswant Singh II. The building is famous for its thin marble walls. This makes Jaswant Thada look quite magical.

**Jaswant Thada, Jodhpur**

**Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê (4.5/5)**

**Location:** Jaswant Thada is a stunning white marble memorial located just a short distance from Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur, Rajasthan. Perched on a small hill, it offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Blue City and the imposing Mehrangarh Fort.

**Architecture & Ambience:**
This architectural gem, often referred to as the "Taj Mahal of Marwar," is a serene and peaceful retreat. Built in 1899 in memory of Maharaja Jaswant Singh II, the structure is made of intricately carved white marble that glows golden in the sunlight. The delicate latticework, domed pavilions, and beautifully landscaped gardens create a tranquil atmosphere, making it a perfect escape from the bustling city.

**Highlights:**
- The main memorial houses portraits of Jodhpur‚Äôs rulers and a royal cenotaph.
- The serene lake beside the monument enhances its beauty.
- The cool breeze and quiet surroundings make it an ideal spot for photography and relaxation.
- The vantage point offers one of the best views of Jodhpur‚Äôs blue houses and Mehrangarh Fort.

**Visitor Experience:**
Entry is reasonably priced, and the site is well-maintained. It‚Äôs less crowded than other tourist spots in Jodhpur, allowing visitors to explore at a leisurely pace. Guides are available for those interested in learning about the history, but the site is equally enjoyable for silent admiration.

**Final Verdict:**
Jaswant Thada is a must-visit for history buffs, architecture lovers, and anyone seeking a peaceful moment with a spectacular view. Its ethereal beauty and historical significance make it one of Jodhpur‚Äôs most underrated attractions.

**Tip:** Visit during sunrise or sunset for the most magical lighting and cooler temperatures.

**Highly recommended!**

Made in memory of Maharaja Jaswant Singh, the white-marble building is minutes from Mehrangarh Fort, and depicts lovely sculptures, beautiful domes and a striking peacock memorial.Jaswant Thada is highly praised for its stunning architecture and serene atmosphere, often referred to as the 'Taj Mahal of Marwar.' Visitors appreciate the beautiful white marble structure, well-maintained gardens, and breathtaking views of Mehrangarh Fort and the surrounding landscape. The site is ideal for photography and peaceful reflection, making it a must-visit for history lovers and families.
1.The memorial remains open from 9 a.m. -5 p.m.
2. Arrive early morning to avoid the crowd and the afternoon heat, and early evening if you want to see the sunset.

placeMetadata.name: Toorji Ka Jhalra Bavdi

sources.snippet: Built-in 1740, Toorji ka Jhalra is one of the most mind-boggling historical places in Jodhpur because of the 250-year old tradition that it holds. This rose-sandstone step has been submerged for many decades now, and its restoration in the current years uncovered this hard-carved treasure. You can spend a few hours exploring the architectural wonder that was used by royal women from illustrious families.
sources.shortName: 10 Historical Places in Jodhpur

sources.snippet: Toorji Ka Jhalra (Toorji‚Äôs Step Well) was built in Jodhpur the 1740s by a Queen, Maharaja Abhay Singh‚Äôs Consort, continuing an age old tradition that Royal women would build public water works. As with all step wells, the steps follow the fluctuating water table down to provide easy all-year round access. Interestingly this well was submerged and full of debris for decades.
sources.shortName: Top 5 architectural marvels to visit in Jodhpur

sources.snippet: When the entire year‚Äôs rainfall comes at once, water management assumes paramount importance. Jodhpur‚Äôs average monsoon season yields less than a foot (32 cm) of rain, so every drop needs to be collected and preserved. Hence the design of the region‚Äôs unique stepwells, or baori: steps running along the sides allow for a steep drop, which minimizes surface evaporation.
sources.shortName: The Architecture of Jodhpur, India‚Äôs Blue City

sources.snippet: Toorji Ka Jhalra was built during the reign of Maharaja Abhai Singh Rathore. He was in charge of Jodhpur from 1724 to 1749. The female members of the Royal families at the time, especially the Queens, would take part in and oversee efforts to erect public water systems.
sources.shortName: 6 Unmissable monuments in Jodhpur and the history behind them

sources.snippet: Toorji Ka Jhalra is an old stepwell in the middle of Jodhpur. This one was built in the 1740s by a king but by a queen ‚Äì the wife of Maharaja Abhay Singh. The well is famous for its beautiful design.

placeMetadata.name: Umaid Bhawan Palace, Jodhpur

sources.snippet: A very close second would be the Umaid Bhavan Palace (now a hotel managed by the Taj Group), which is built on a smaller hill. The former Jodhpur ruler, Maharaja Umaid Singh, initiated construction of the palace in 1929 and finished it in 1943. Among the world‚Äôs largest private residences, its rose-pink structure is a visual amalgam of multiple architecture styles.
sources.shortName: An insider's guide to Jodhpur: blue buildings and green energy | Cities

sources.snippet: A royal palace, a hotel, and a museum, the Umaid Bhawan Palace was built between 1929 ‚Äì 1943 and named after the then-king, Maharaja Umaid Singh. To help the farmers, devasted by the three-year-long droughts, the Maharaja decided to build a lavish palace to provide them with a chance at surviving the harsh conditions. Henry Vaughan Lanchester, a contemporary of Edwin Lutyens, was commissioned to prepare the plans for the structure.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Jodhpur for Travelling Architect

sources.snippet: If you are in the mood to experience the luxurious side of Jodhpur then you cannot miss out on the Umaid Bhawan Palace. It is one of the most prominent historical places in Jodhpur that is both an exquisite structure and a celebrated destination. It houses a museum in its premises that lets you revel in the beauty of the galleries storing regal items.
sources.shortName: 10 Historical Places in Jodhpur

sources.snippet: The last of the grand palaces in India is an epitome of Jodhpur's royal heritage that is a sign of nobility and an architectural marvel. A Royal Experience Like No Other ‚Äì Umaid Bhawan Palace is Pure Magic!

Staying at Umaid Bhawan Palace was nothing short of a dream come true. From the moment we arrived at this majestic sandstone marvel, we were transported into a world of regal opulence, impeccable hospitality, and timeless elegance.

The palace itself is a masterpiece‚Äîan architectural wonder blending Indo-Deco style with Rajput grandeur. Set amidst lush gardens and perched high above Jodhpur, the views of the Blue City and the Mehrangarh Fort are absolutely breathtaking.

What truly sets Umaid Bhawan apart is the warmth and professionalism of the staff. Every member of the team especially Mr. Gordhan Singh Ji, Mr. Sikander Singh Ji, Mr. Jabar Singh Ji, Mr. Sajjan Singh Ji, Mr. Karan Singh Ji, Mr. Hukum Singh Ji and Mr. Umaid Singh Ji made us feel like royalty. Their attention to detail, genuine smiles, and readiness to go the extra mile made our stay extraordinary.

Our Suite Room was spacious, beautifully furnished, and steeped in history, yet equipped with every modern comfort. The bed was luxurious, the bathroom was grand, and the heritage decor added a unique charm that made us feel like we were living in a bygone era.

Dining at the palace was a culinary delight. Each meal at Risala and Pillars was not just delicious, but also beautifully presented, with a menu that honored local Rajasthani flavors while offering international finesse.

We also thoroughly enjoyed the spa, the vintage car tour, and simply strolling through the manicured gardens. Every corner of the property tells a story, and the history is palpable in the best way.

Umaid Bhawan Palace is more than just a hotel‚Äîit‚Äôs an experience, a celebration of heritage, and a rare glimpse into a regal lifestyle that most only read about. Whether you're seeking luxury, romance, or cultural richness, this place delivers on every front. We left with hearts full of gratitude and memories to last a lifetime.

5 stars is simply not enough. Highly, highly recommended.

placeMetadata.name: Mehrangarh Fort

sources.snippet: That would have to be the sprawling Mehrangarh Fort, which dominates the Jodhpur skyline. Built in around 1460 by the founder of Jodhpur, Rao Jodhya, it sits atop Bhaurcheeria hill and is one of India‚Äôs largest and most magnificent forts.
sources.shortName: An insider's guide to Jodhpur: blue buildings and green energy | Cities

sources.snippet: The beautiful Fort situated on top of a 400-feet-high hill is a testament to the rich cultural history of the erstwhile ruling dynasty and is home to one of the best museums of the state with prized exhibits ‚Äì artwork, arms and armoury, textiles, etc. With the foundation for the Fort laid in the mid-15th Century by the Rajput Chief Rao Jodha, the extravagant structure‚Äôs construction took over 500 years to complete to become the piece of architectural brilliance and grandeur it is today, the crown jewel of Jodhpur. The Fort also consists of important palaces like the Sheesh Mahal, Phool Mahal, Moti Mahal, etc., and provides breathtaking views of the entire city.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Jodhpur for Travelling Architect

sources.snippet: Commissioned in 1460 by Rao Jodha, this gigantic fort situated at 400 feet above round is a sight to behold right at the heart of the Jodhpur city. Mehrangarh Fort is truly one of the most magnificent landmarks of Jodhpur. It is huge, beautiful, and steeped in history. A lift service is available (‚Çπ50 one-way) that takes you up to the higher levels of the fort, saving time and effort. From there, you still need to explore some sections on foot, especially to see the Diwan-e-Aam (Hall of Public Audience) and  Diwan-e-Khas (Hall of Private Audience).
One of the highlights of the fort is the breathtaking view of the Blue City of Jodhpur, best enjoyed from the top floors where the old cannons are placed. The panoramic view is truly mesmerizing, especially in the evening light.
It is highly recommended to hire a local guide. ( Rs.400 for 4 people )They explain the rich history, legends, and architectural details that you might otherwise miss. The fort also houses a well-maintained museum, which displays royal artifacts such as ancient swords, armory, traditional costumes, miniature paintings, palanquins, elephant seats (howdahs), and other treasures of Rajasthan‚Äôs royal heritage.
Mehrangarh is a must-visit attraction in Jodhpur, but do keep in mind that the fort is vast and requires time to explore properly. Plan to spend at least
2‚Äì3 hours here to cover the main sections comfortably.
If you have more time, you can also enjoy cultural performances and traditional music often held in the fort courtyard, which add to the royal experience.

Mehrangarh is a historic fort located in Jodhpur, Rajasthan, India. It stands on a hilltop, rising about 122 m (400 ft) above the surrounding plains, and the complex spans 1,200 acres (486 hectares). It was initially built around 1459 by the Rajput ruler of Rathore clan Rao Jodha,though most of the existing structure is from the 17th century built by his successors. The fort has seven gates, which includes main entrance Jai Pol (meaning 'victory gate'), built by Maharaja Man Singh to commemorate his victories over the Jaipur and Bikaner armies in 1806. The Fattehpol (lit.‚Äâ'victory gate'), commemorates victory of Maharaja Ajit Singh over the Mughals. The English writer and Nobel Prize winner, Rudyard Kipling, described the fort as "a palace that might have been built by Titans and colored by the morning sun."A beautiful magnificent fort with a magnificent history. Ancient lovely building with multiple floors. For the convenience of tourists a paid lift is installed. üìåAn Unforgettable Journey Through Time -
Stepping into Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur is not just visiting a monument; it's a profound journey back in time. Perched dramatically on a 400-foot-high cliff, this colossal fortress is a masterpiece of architecture, history, and culture that will leave you in awe. From the moment you approach its immense, towering walls, you understand why Rudyard Kipling called it "the work of giants."

The fort's exterior, carved from burnished red sandstone, seems to merge seamlessly with the rugged hill, creating an image of impregnable strength and natural beauty. But the true magic lies within. The intricately carved palaces, such as the stunning Moti Mahal, Phool Mahal, and Sheesh Mahal, are a testament to the opulence and artistic brilliance of the Rajput rulers. Each courtyard and room tells a story, beautifully preserved and brought to life by the excellent audio guide, which is highly recommended and well worth the minimal cost.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Mehrangarh is the incredible panoramic view it offers. From the ramparts, you can gaze out over the "Blue City" of Jodhpur, a sea of indigo houses that creates a mesmerizing contrast against the arid landscape. The feeling of standing at this vantage point, with the wind carrying the echoes of centuries of history, is simply breathtaking.

Magnificent fort with breathtaking views of Jodhpur‚Äôs Blue City. The museum is well-curated, showcasing royal artifacts, arms, and palanquins. Architecture is grand and well-preserved. Entry is a bit pricey, and it involves a lot of walking/climbing, but totally worth the experience.

The majestic fort boasts art and history to itself.
One of the must visit place when you are jodhpur.

placeMetadata.name: Mandore Garden

sources.snippet: Among the best-preserved sites of Jodhpur is the magnificent Mandore Gardens in the ancient town of Mandore. The town served as the capital of the erstwhile ruling dynasty of Marwar until it was deserted in 1459 CE. The Mandore garden s still stand strong after fighting the trials of time to narrate the tale of the town‚Äôs rich heritage.
sources.shortName: 15 Places to Visit in Jodhpur for Travelling Architect

sources.snippet: One of the notable historical places in Jodhpur has to be the Mandore Gardens because it is an architectural masterpiece. Brimming with old temples, and cenotaphs, this wonderful destination can take you back in history. There is a hall of heroes that is dedicated to the heroes of Rajput folk with several deities that stand near it.

sources.snippet: On the northern outskirts of modern Jodhpur, the Mandore Gardens complex offers a break from the tough desert landscape. Here the rocks give way to lanes brimming with sandstone chhatri set among leafy trees and fountains. It‚Äôs an idyllic spot for humans and monkeys alike.

The garden is also home to a museum, statues of deities and local heroes, and lots of monkeys roaming around, which adds a lively touch. It‚Äôs a good place for history lovers, photographers, and families looking for a relaxed outing.

sources.snippet: One of the most popular places and temples to visit in the city, the Mahamandir Temple is a 19th-century  exquisite architectural marvel dedicated to Lord Shiva. The structure stands on 84 beautiful and intricately carved pillars depicting various yoga postures with well-designed traditional motifs studded onto the pillars and walls of the sacred place. The place is a must-visit not just for its religious sanctity but for witnessing its beauty and ambience.

reviews.reviewText:
During my solo trip, I usually prefer walking and using public transport. However, due to the scorching heat in Jodhpur, I decided to book an auto-rickshaw for the entire second day. After visiting the Mandore area and other sites, I asked the driver to head towards Mahamandir Temple. To my surprise, he wasn't familiar with the spot, so I showed him the location on Google Maps.

Mahamandir Temple is an ancient and historical site in Jodhpur, but it's not prominently visible from the outside. Interestingly, a government secondary school, primarily for underprivileged children, operates within the complex. The temple was constructed in 1812 under the patronage of the Marwar rulers of Jodhpur.

What struck me most about Mahamandir Temple is its design. The temple is renowned for its over 80 intricately sculpted columns, each unique in design and meaning. These pillars support the structure and are adorned with elaborate carvings depicting various aspects of Hindu mythology, nature, and celestial beings. The walls and ceilings are decorated with stunning frescoes, carvings, and sculptures showcasing the artistic brilliance of the artisans.

Many of these sculptures portray scenes from the life of Lord Shiva, his consort Parvati, and other deities from the Hindu pantheon. The artwork also reflects traditional Rajasthani themes, including flora, fauna, and geometric patterns, all etched with remarkable detail.

The sanctum of the temple, where the main deity Lord Shiva is housed, is a serene and peaceful space. Notably, Shivaratri is grandly celebrated here, along with other related occasions, featuring Rajasthani dance performances and traditional music.

My driver was thrilled to discover this temple, just like me. He mentioned that he had guided many tourists, including foreign travelers, but was unaware of this temple's existence. He felt sorry for them, saying they might have missed out.

Entry to the temple is officially free, as I had heard earlier. However, an elderly woman asked us for an entry charge of Rs 40 per head. Although the amount might be slightly higher than expected, I gave it to her willingly, understanding that donations or tickets are sometimes necessary to maintain historical and holy sites.

The Mahamandir Temple is a beautiful Hindu temple located in Jodhpur, Rajasthan, India. It is renowned for its intricate architecture and exquisite stone carvings. The temple was built in 1812 AD by Maharaja Shiv Singh, and it is dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple's 84 intricately carved pillars and the detailed sculptures on its walls make it a popular attraction for visitors interested in art, architecture, and religious heritage. However it is now converted into a government school and due to lack of maintenance it is leading to deterioration of the structure and loss of its historical and cultural significance. It's essential for authorities to prioritize the preservation and upkeep of such sites to safeguard their heritage value for the benefit of present and future generations.

The Mahamandir Temple, a 19th-century, beautiful monument built in honor of Lord Shiva, gives visitors an intriguing mix of spiritual peace and architectural grandeur. Constructed during 1812 by Maharaja Shiv Singh, this temple is located roughly 2 kilometers from the city center, a reflection of the artistry, splendor, and religiosity of its era.
As soon as they arrive, tourists are awed by the massive structure of the temple, which is made entirely of red sandstone. The walls have exquisitely carved figures of Hindu gods and beautiful traditional Rajasthani designs, depicting the masterful workmanship of that time. The beautiful pictures of Lord Ganesh and Hanuman adorn the main entrance, which opens to a large courtyard that contains shrines to different Hindu gods.
The temple's most prominent feature is the assembly hall that is held up by 84 intricately carved pillars. Each pillar is an original work of art, featuring different yogic positions and fascinating stories from Indian mythology. These elaborate sculptures are not only an artistic beauty but also provide insights into the cultural and religious practices of the past. The sanctum sanctorum contains a large black stone lingam, one of the biggest in India, and is well-adorned with paintings and carvings depicting the life and mythology of Lord Shiva.
The Mahamandir Temple complex spreads from the principal shrine to include minor temples and a serene garden with a tiny pond, adding to the peaceful environment. Although it is less crowded than some other major temples in Jodhpur, this comparative quiet adds to its peaceful ambiance and makes it a perfect spot for contemplation and prayer.
For history, architecture, and religious heritage seekers, the Mahamandir Temple is a travel must. Its beautiful carvings, rich history, and religious importance provide a deep experience, giving a glimpse of Rajasthan's art and culture heritage. To experience it in all its beauty and serenity, visit it in the morning early or late afternoon. Note that recent reports indicate that there is a school on the temple premises, and visits may be limited during school time. It is best to check visiting hours prior to organizing your visit.

Mahamandir Temple Jodhpur - Tranquil Beauty

placeMetadata.name: Umaid Bhawan Museum

sources.snippet: The last royal palace erected before India's independence was the Umaid Bhawan Palace. It is also known as the Chittar Palace because of its position atop Chittar Hill. Its foundations were established in 1929, and it was finished in 1943.The Taj Group of Hotels first allowed visitors to the palace who wanted to experience living in a royal house in 2006.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Umaid Bhawan Museum, located in Jodhpur city, is a popular tourist spot and one of the best attractions in the area. The museum is housed within a portion of the majestic Umaid Bhawan Palace, with other parts serving as a luxurious hotel and residence for the royal family. It showcases an impressive collection of antiques that belonged to the maharajas and displays intricate artwork, providing insight into the history of the Suryvanshi dynasty.

The museum is small but elegant ‚Äì showcasing royal artifacts, vintage clocks, weapons, and a classic car collection that history lovers will enjoy. The palace gardens are beautifully maintained and perfect for photography.

reviews.reviewText: It's NOT a tourist place. It is a highly RESTRICTED AREA which is Out of Bounds for the General Public. The Palace was once an area which housed "Raika Community" and their camels. Gradually, in the year 1663 by the queen of Maharaja Jaswant Singh I (Hadi Rani Jasrang De), constructed an exquisite lawn and Garden in this area, hence renaming it as "Raika Bagh". Later a Place cum Garden Complex was constructed along with Maharaja's Official Guest House, further renaming it as "Raika Bagh Palace". It was here that in 1883, Swami Dayanand Saraswati came to Jodhpur. The arrangements for his public audience were made in the public ground of this palace only. He gave his sermons here itself. Even Jaswant Singh used to listen to Swami Dayanand in this palace. But Unfortunately, a tragedy occurred when Swami Dayanand Saraswati was poisoned on 29th September 1883, while being royal guest. It is said it was Dayananda‚Äôs own cook who conspired with the court dancer to mix crushed Glass in his milk. It is even Rumoured that Queen Zubeida's unsatisfied soul (Second wife of King Hanwant Singh I of Marwar, who died with him in a Mysterious Plane Crash) still  haunts this palace and the royal family's school near the palace.

Balsamand Lake is a lake situated 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) from Jodhpur on Jodhpur-Mandore Road. This lake is a popular picnic spot, built in 1159 AD by Gurjara-Pratihara rulers. It was designed as a water reservoir to provide water to Mandore. The lake has a length of one kilometre (0.62 mi), breadth of 50 metres (160 ft) and a depth of 15 metres (49 ft).
The Balsamand Lake Palace was built later as a summer palace on its shore. The lake is surrounded by lush green gardens that house groves of trees like¬†mango,¬†papaya,¬†pomegranate,¬†guava¬†and¬†plum. Animals and birds like the jackal and peacock also call this place home.
Balsamand Lake is an artificial lake that was built way back in 1159 AD by Balak Rao Parihar as a water reservoir to cater for Mandore. One kilometre long, 50 m broad and 15 m deep; the lake is located in the middle of a manicured garden full of mango, papaya, pomegranate, guava and plum trees. Jackal and peacock are the prominent guests in the garden. There is an impressive red sandstone summer palace on the shores of the lake, which is now converted into a five-star property. Make a point to watch out for pesky monkeys when walking the nature trails. The area is a popular picnic spot for locals.

An Oasis of joy in the middle of a desert. Beautiful gardens, gorgeous rooms and a sense of being detached from time itself. A place that takes you away from it all and helps you to get to know someone that you had not really taken pains to know for some time....yourself.

placeMetadata.name: Ghanta Ghar Jodhpur

sources.snippet: Around 200 years ago, Maharaja Sardar Singh of Jodhpur constructed the majestic clock tower known as the Ghanta Ghar in the heart of the city. This clock is manufactured by the same company that manufactured the clock tower in London. As the only clock tower in Rajasthan, it's a celebrated landmark marking the gateway to Old Jodhpur, often referred to as the clock tower of Rajasthan.

reviews.reviewText: The most hustling and bustling place in Jodhpur. Daytime you can dedicate for shopping from the tiny lanes dedicated for clothes, bangles and what not. In the midst of the lanes you would come across many savouries to devour.  Evening time you can stroll and look well lit clock tower and the fort presenting a great opportunity for photo enthusiasts. Standing near the clock tower you can imagine how well planned the cities would be in ancient times.

This historic clock tower was built in 1909 with a clock imported from London. It‚Äôs located right in the center of Sardar Market and serves as a prominent landmark.

I‚Äôve been visiting this area for over 10 years since my first trip, but unfortunately the dusty conditions remain unchanged. Every time a rickshaw passes by, clouds of dust still kick up from the unpaved roads, which can be quite uncomfortable.

While it‚Äôs possible to enter the clock tower itself, I didn‚Äôt find much merit in going inside, so I chose to skip visiting inside. The tower is impressive enough from the outside and worth seeing as part of exploring the bustling Sardar Market.

This monument built in the centre of the city, with tickets priced at 25/- per person is good to go. It provides good views of the mehergarh fort.

Historically it has been for hundreds of years, with the maintenance of the clock tower handed to a particular family down the generations.

Surrounding it is the sardar market, which is good for vegetables, spices, local handicrafts and general grocery items.

Ghanta ghar or Clock Tower is one of the iconic landmark of Jodhpur city, surrounded by huge Sardar Market. During day time it is a bit crowded but at night time this place looks quite peaceful. Meherangarh fort is also visible from this place. The market around ghanta ghar is also worth visiting.

It is one of the main attractions in Jodhpur. It is located in the busiest market of Jodhpur i.e. Sardar Market which is adjacent to Nai Sarak. Can do shopping here. Don't come here by own car as finding parking is almost impossible. The Clock Tower also called Ghanta Ghar looks beautiful during night. We can go up the tower as well (up to a certain point) by taking a ticket of minimal price.

The best shopping and beautiful attraction is the clock tower.

For anyone visiting Jodhpur, Caf√© Sheesh Mahal is an essential stop, especially for tourists seeking a delightful blend of modern comforts and traditional charm. Situated in the heart of the city, this caf√© offers a serene escape from the vibrant streets of Jodhpur. The ambiance is unparalleled, making it one of the most inviting spots in the city. With its elegant decor and intimate seating, it provides the perfect setting to unwind, enjoy a meal, or simply soak in the atmosphere.

Equally impressive are their pancakes, light and fluffy, served with a variety of toppings to suit all tastes. Whether you're looking for a quick snack or a leisurely meal, Caf√© Sheesh Mahal delivers with its thoughtfully curated menu.

Its central location makes it an ideal stop for tourists, providing a convenient respite after exploring the nearby attractions. The staff are warm and attentive, ensuring an experience that is as enjoyable as it is relaxed.

In a city steeped in culture and history, Caf√© Sheesh Mahal offers a refreshing yet authentic experience. It perfectly encapsulates the fusion of Jodhpur‚Äôs rich heritage with a contemporary dining environment, making it a must-visit for anyone seeking both culinary satisfaction and a memorable ambiance.

placeMetadata.name: Phool Mahal Palace

sources.snippet: An integral part of the Mehrangarh Fort, the Phool Mahal is a beautifully decorated hall that is believed to have served the Maharajas as a pleasure dome where numerous entertaining events for the kings took place. As the name suggests, the design of the hall was done in a manner to make it look as beautiful as a beautiful blossoming flower. The ceiling of the hall consists of delicate gold filigree work along with remarkable paintings and portraits (like the raga mala series) and pristine furniture from the British era, which glorifies the essence and the aesthetics of the room.

reviews.reviewText:
The Mehrangarh Fort is one of the largest forts in the country and is known for its architectural beauty and historical significance. The fort houses several palaces, each with its own unique features and history.
Phool Mahal is an exquisite palace known for its intricate gold filigree work, paintings, and mirror work. It was created as a pleasure dome by Maharaja Abhaya Singh and was used for entertainment and festivities.

**A Majestic Marvel in the Blue City**

Mehrangarh Fort, towering 400 feet above Jodhpur, is not just a historical monument but a breathtaking symbol of Rajasthan‚Äôs grandeur. Built in the 15th century by Rao Jodha, the fort‚Äôs imposing walls and intricate architecture leave visitors spellbound.

### **Highlights:**
- **Architecture & Views:** The fort‚Äôs massive gates, ornate palaces (like Moti Mahal and Phool Mahal), and expansive courtyards showcase Rajput craftsmanship. The panoramic views of Jodhpur‚Äôs blue houses from the ramparts are unforgettable.
- **Museum:** One of the best in Rajasthan, it houses an exquisite collection of palanquins, arms, costumes, and royal artifacts. The audio guide (narrated by Shah Rukh Khan) adds a fascinating touch.
- **Cultural Experience:** Live folk music performances and the famous "Jodhpur RIFF" festival make the fort come alive with Rajasthani culture.
- **Chokelao Bagh & Caf√©:** A serene garden and rooftop caf√© offering delicious local snacks with a stunning fort backdrop.

### **Tips:**
- Visit early morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds and heat.
- Don‚Äôt miss the "Chamunda Devi Temple" and the thrilling "Jayapol" victory gate.
- Photography enthusiasts will love the endless photo opportunities.

**** Mehrangarh Fort is a must-visit for history buffs, architecture lovers, and anyone seeking a glimpse into Rajasthan‚Äôs royal past. Its sheer scale, beauty, and cultural richness make it one of India‚Äôs finest forts.

**** A mesmerizing journey through time‚Äîhighly recommended!

The Phool Mahal, or "Palace of Flowers," is one of the most exquisitely decorated and historically significant chambers within the Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur, Rajasthan.
Built in the 18th century by Maharaja Abhaya Singh, it served as a private audience hall and a space for royal entertainment and leisure. The name "Phool Mahal" itself suggests its vibrant beauty, as its interiors are designed to evoke the essence of a blooming flower.
Here's what makes it so remarkable:
* Opulent Decor: The palace is renowned for its extravagant decoration, featuring intricate frescoes, elaborate carvings, and richly colored wall paintings. The walls and ceilings are adorned with gold leaf work, often using gold brought from Gujarat, creating a lavish and regal ambiance.
* Artistic Excellence: You'll find a stunning display of Rajput and Mughal artistry, including detailed mirror work, delicate filigree, and vivid murals depicting royal life, traditional motifs, and even illustrations from the famous Raga Mala series (Indian classical music compositions). Portraits of Jodhpur's ancestors also grace the walls.
* Exclusive Use: Unlike some other parts of the fort, Phool Mahal was a private and exclusive chamber, primarily used by the Maharaja for private gatherings, entertainment by female dancers, and as a personal retreat. This exclusivity is reflected in its less accessible location within the fort.
* Historical Significance: It stands as a testament to the grandeur and artistic patronage of the Rathore rulers of Jodhpur, offering a glimpse into the lavish lifestyle of the royal family.
Today, Phool Mahal is a key part of the Mehrangarh Fort museum, allowing visitors to step back in time and admire its unique blend of architectural beauty and artistic splendor.

Many paraphernalia for Madh/Wine storage & drinking are on display here. You will also learn about the lineage of kings in almost entirety. The paintings depicting festive scenarios & scenes from the bygone era are an extremely fine work. The Phool Mahal is a beautifully decorated hall in the Mehrangarh fort, Jodhpur. The hall probably served the purpose of a pleasure dome of the Maharajas, and the female dancers used to stay here. Accordingly the room was made to look as beautiful as a magnificent flower, which earned it the name Phool mahal. The ceiling has golden filigree work, for which it is said, gold was brought from Ahmedabad, Gujarat. There are also some beautiful portraits and paintings, especially the raga mala series, and furniture from the British period to enhance the glory of the room.

placeMetadata.description: Large Hindu temple with dramatic views of Jodhpur, with a serene vibe, except on festival days.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Shree Chamunda Mata Temple, located on the southern edge of Jodhpur's landmark fort, is a popular Hindu temple with stunning views of the city. The temple houses a black stone idol of Mother Chamunda and is known for its serene atmosphere, except during festival days when it becomes lively. Nestled within the vibrant city, this divine sanctuary offers visitors a spiritual journey and an immersive experience in its tranquil and devotional ambiance.

reviews.reviewText: This temple is situated inside the mehrangad fortress. One will have to walk all the way to this end point of the fort. This is the only temple in the premises of Mehrangad and the royal family used to offer puja here. There is a separate route for females and kids to go to this temple and a stairway to this temple for the men. Since we went to this temple during the sunset we witnessed a beautiful and mesmerizing sunset here. A note to the elderly, kindly take the elevator to the top of the fort and take a walk around as it is a huge place to walk and cover.

The Temple is inside the Mehrangarh Fort. The scenic and serene beauty in and around the temple surpasses the beauty of the fort! Interacting with the Pandit Ji (Tiwari Ji) doing puja there would also be a memorable experience as he may tell you the brief history of the temple.

Chamunda Mata Temple is a peaceful and spiritually uplifting place nestled within Mehrangarh Fort. The temple itself is small but holds deep historical and religious significance for the locals. What truly makes this spot special is the breathtaking bird‚Äôs-eye view of Jodhpur‚Äôs iconic blue houses‚Äîan unforgettable sight!

The atmosphere is serene, with a cool breeze and fewer crowds compared to other parts of the fort. It‚Äôs a perfect place to pause, soak in the beauty of the Blue City, and experience a moment of tranquility.

The Chamunda Mata Temple, nestled within the magnificent Mehrangarh Fort, is an absolute must-visit in Jodhpur. Even if you're primarily at the fort for its history and architecture, take the time to visit this sacred spot ‚Äì it offers a completely different, yet equally enriching, experience.

Nestled in the vibrant city of Jodhpur, the Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shree Chamunda Mata Temple is a divine sanctuary that leaves an indelible impression on the soul. Visiting this sacred haven is akin to embarking on a spiritual journey, immersing oneself in the divine aura that permeates every corner of this tranquil space.

Upon entering the temple premises, one is greeted by the resounding echoes of devotional chants, creating an atmosphere of serenity and devotion. The architecture of the temple is awe-inspiring, reflecting a harmonious blend of traditional design and intricate detailing. The vivid colors, ornate carvings, and sacred symbols adorning the temple walls contribute to its visual splendor.

Inside, the sanctum dedicated to Shree Chamunda Mata exudes an energy that is both powerful and peaceful. Devotees engage in heartfelt prayers, seeking solace and divine blessings. The temple's priests, with their deep knowledge and spiritual guidance, enhance the overall spiritual experience.

One cannot help but marvel at the panoramic views of Jodhpur that the temple offers. Positioned strategically, it provides a breathtaking vantage point, allowing visitors to absorb the beauty of the city while basking in the divine presence of the Chamunda Mata.

The temple's management ensures a well-maintained and clean environment, adding to the positive experience of devotees and visitors alike. Whether you're a devout worshiper or a curious traveler seeking cultural enrichment, the Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shree Chamunda Mata Temple promises an enriching and spiritually uplifting experience in the heart of Jodhpur.

The Shree Chamunda Mata Temple in Jodhpur is a significant religious site dedicated to the Hindu goddess Chamunda, also known as Chamundi. The temple is located inside the Mehrangarh fort. It offers devotees stunning views of the surrounding landscape. Chamunda Mata is revered as a fierce manifestation of the Divine Mother, known for her protection and blessings. The temple attracts pilgrims and tourists alike, seeking spiritual solace and the opportunity to witness the temple's intricate architecture and religious ceremonies.

Chamunda Mataji Mandir is situated inside Meherangarh Fort Complex. You need to remove your shoes before starting to climb the stairs to the temple. Clicking pictures is not allowed inside the temple complex. It remains crowded, especially by women devotees.

There are two routes to this temple, via steps or a circular path. Both are unique in their own way.
Navaratri is very special here

I recently visited the famous Sweet Shop.
it's safe to say that this place lives up to its reputation. The sweet shop is renowned for its delectable Gulab Jamun, Mishri Gunja, and Pede. Hygiene is impeccable, with a perfect 10 on 10 score.
Gulab Jamun is the star attraction here, and for good reason. I must say, it's unbeatable in taste. If you're in Jodhpur or planning a visit, trying their Gulab Jamun is a must. The service is quick, and the Gulab jamun  priced at 500 per kilogram.
I frequently eat the Gulab Jamun and Rabdi, and I absolutely loved them. The flavors and quality are outstanding.
One thing to note is that the entrance is not wheelchair accessible due to small stairs, but it shouldn't be an issue for those who can use stairs. Overall, a delightful sweet shop with top-notch sweets and quick service. Highly recommended for a sweet indulgence in Jodhpur
